para.emphasis: If we do an adjoint computation, we need a SpaceTransformation, which has the same properties as the primal one but measures in transformed coordinates.

literallayout.computeroutput: 1 #ifndef DualProblemTransformationWrapperFlag 2 #define DualProblemTransformationWrapperFlag 3 4 #include <deal.II/base/point.h> 5 #include <deal.II/base/tensor.h> 6 #include <deal.II/lac/vector.h> 7 #include <math.h> 8 #include <vector> 9 #include "../Core/Sector.h" 10 #include "SpaceTransformation.h" 11 12 using namespace dealii; 13 14 /** 15 * \class DualProblemTransformationWrapper 16 * \brief If we do an adjoint computation, we need a SpaceTransformation, which 17 * has the same properties as the primal one but measures in transformed 18 * coordinates. This Wrapper contains the space transformation of the primal 19 * version but maps input parameters to their dual equivalent. 20 * 21 * Essentially this class enables us to write a waveguide class which is unaware 22 * of its being primal or dual. Using this wrapper makes us compute the solution 23 * of the inverse order shape parametrization. \author Pascal Kraft 24 * \date 1.12.2016 25 */ 26 class DualProblemTransformationWrapper : public SpaceTransformation { 27 public: 28 /** 29 * Since this object encapsulates another Space Transformation, the 30 * construction is straight forward. \param non_dual_st This pointer points to 31 * the actual transformation that is being wrapped. 32 */ 33 DualProblemTransformationWrapper(SpaceTransformation *non_dual_st, int rank); 34 35 ~DualProblemTransformationWrapper(); 36 37 /** 38 * One of the core functionalities of a SpaceTransformation is to map a 39 * mathematical coordinate to a physical one (so an transformed to an 40 * untransformed coordinate). \param coord the coordinate to be transformed. 41 * In this class we simply pass the 42 */ 43 Point<3> math_to_phys(Point<3> coord) const; 44 45 /** 46 * This function does the same as math_to_phys only in the opposit direction. 47 * \param coord the coordinate to be transformed. 48 */ 49 Point<3> phys_to_math(Point<3> coord) const; 50 51 /** 52 * In order to test implementation, this function was added to check, if the 53 * transformation-tensor at a given coordinate is the identity or not. \param 54 * coord This is the coordinate to test. 55 */ 56 bool is_identity(Point<3> coord) const; 57 58 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> get_Tensor(Point<3> &coordinate) const; 59 60 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> get_Preconditioner_Tensor( 61 Point<3> &coordinate, int block) const; 62 63 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> Apply_PML_To_Tensor( 64 Point<3> &coordinate, Tensor<2, 3, double> Tensor_input) const; 65 66 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> Apply_PML_To_Tensor_For_Preconditioner( 67 Point<3> &coordinate, Tensor<2, 3, double> Tensor_input, int block) const; 68 69 Tensor<2, 3, double> get_Space_Transformation_Tensor( 70 Point<3> &coordinate) const; 71 72 Tensor<2, 3, double> get_Space_Transformation_Tensor_Homogenized( 73 Point<3> &coordinate) const; 74 75 const double XMinus, XPlus, YMinus, YPlus, ZMinus, ZPlus; 76 77 /** 78 * This function is used to determine, if a system-coordinate belongs to a 79 * PML-region for the PML that limits the computational domain along the 80 * x-axis. Since there are 3 blocks of PML-type material, there are 3 81 * functions. \param position Stores the position in which to test for 82 * presence of a PML-Material. 83 */ 84 bool PML_in_X(Point<3> &position) const; 85 86 /** 87 * This function is used to determine, if a system-coordinate belongs to a 88 * PML-region for the PML that limits the computational domain along the 89 * y-axis. Since there are 3 blocks of PML-type material, there are 3 90 * functions. \param position Stores the position in which to test for 91 * presence of a PML-Material. 92 */ 93 bool PML_in_Y(Point<3> &position) const; 94 95 /** 96 * This function is used to determine, if a system-coordinate belongs to a 97 * PML-region for the PML that limits the computational domain along the 98 * z-axis. Since there are 3 blocks of PML-type material, there are 3 99 * functions. \param position Stores the position in which to test for 100 * presence of a PML-Material. 101 */ 102 bool PML_in_Z(Point<3> &position) const; 103 104 /** 105 * This function fulfills the same purpose as those with similar names but it 106 * is supposed to be used together with Preconditioner_PML_in_Z instead of the 107 * versions without "Preconditioner". 108 */ 109 double Preconditioner_PML_Z_Distance(Point<3> &p, unsigned int block) const; 110 111 /** 112 * This function calculates for a given point, its distance to a PML-boundary 113 * limiting the computational domain. This function is used merely to make 114 * code more readable. There is a function for every one of the dimensions 115 * since the normal vectors of PML-regions in this implementation are the 116 * coordinate-axis. This value is set to zero outside the PML and positive 117 * inside both PML-domains (only one for the z-direction). \param position 118 * Stores the position from which to calculate the distance to the 119 * PML-surface. 120 */ 121 double PML_X_Distance(Point<3> &position) const; 122 123 /** 124 * This function calculates for a given point, its distance to a PML-boundary 125 * limiting the computational domain. This function is used merely to make 126 * code more readable. There is a function for every one of the dimensions 127 * since the normal vectors of PML-regions in this implementation are the 128 * coordinate-axis. This value is set to zero outside the PML and positive 129 * inside both PML-domains (only one for the z-direction). \param position 130 * Stores the position from which to calculate the distance to the 131 * PML-surface. 132 */ 133 134 double PML_Y_Distance(Point<3> &position) const; 135 /** 136 * This function calculates for a given point, its distance to a PML-boundary 137 * limiting the computational domain. This function is used merely to make 138 * code more readable. There is a function for every one of the dimensions 139 * since the normal vectors of PML-regions in this implementation are the 140 * coordinate-axis. This value is set to zero outside the PML and positive 141 * inside both PML-domains (only one for the z-direction). \param position 142 * Stores the position from which to calculate the distance to the 143 * PML-surface. 144 */ 145 double PML_Z_Distance(Point<3> &position) const; 146 147 /** 148 * This member contains all the Sectors who, as a sum, form the complete 149 * Waveguide. These Sectors are a partition of the simulated domain. 150 */ 151 std::vector<Sector<3>> case_sectors; 152 153 /** 154 * The material-property \f$\epsilon_r\f$ has a different value inside and 155 * outside of the waveguides core. This variable stores its value inside the 156 * core. 157 */ 158 const double epsilon_K; 159 /** 160 * The material-property \f$\epsilon_r\f$ has a different value inside and 161 * outside of the waveguides core. This variable stores its value outside the 162 * core. 163 */ 164 const double epsilon_M; 165 /** 166 * Since the computational domain is split into subdomains (called sectors), 167 * it is important to keep track of the amount of subdomains. This member 168 * stores the number of Sectors the computational domain has been split into. 169 */ 170 const int sectors; 171 172 /** 173 * This value is initialized with the value Delta from the input-file. 174 */ 175 const double deltaY; 176 177 /** 178 * At the beginning (before the first solution of a system) only the boundary 179 * conditions for the shape of the waveguide are known. Therefore the values 180 * for the degrees of freedom need to be estimated. This function sets all 181 * variables to appropiate values and estimates an appropriate shape based on 182 * averages and a polynomial interpolation of the boundary conditions on the 183 * shape. 184 */ 185 void estimate_and_initialize(); 186 187 /** 188 * This member calculates the value of Q1 for a provided \f$z\f$-coordinate. 189 * This value is used in the transformation of the solution-vector in 190 * transformed coordinates (solution of the system-matrix) to real coordinates 191 * (physical field). \param z The value of Q1 is independent of \f$x\f$ and 192 * \f$y\f$. Therefore only a \f$z\f$-coordinate is provided in a call to the 193 * function. 194 */ 195 double get_Q1(double z) const; 196 197 /** 198 * This member calculates the value of Q2 for a provided \f$z\f$-coordinate. 199 * This value is used in the transformation of the solution-vector in 200 * transformed coordinates (solution of the system-matrix) to real coordinates 201 * (physical field). \param z The value of Q2 is independent of \f$x\f$ and 202 * \f$y\f$. Therefore only a \f$z\f$-coordinate is provided in a call to the 203 * function. 204 */ 205 double get_Q2(double z) const; 206 207 /** 208 * This member calculates the value of Q3 for a provided \f$z\f$-coordinate. 209 * This value is used in the transformation of the solution-vector in 210 * transformed coordinates (solution of the system-matrix) to real coordinates 211 * (physical field). \param z The value of Q3 is independent of \f$x\f$ and 212 * \f$y\f$. Therefore only a \f$z\f$-coordinate is provided in a call to the 213 * function. 214 */ 215 double get_Q3(double z) const; 216 217 /** 218 * This is a getter for the values of degrees of freedom. A getter-setter 219 * interface was introduced since the values are estimated automatically 220 * during the optimization and non-physical systems should be excluded from 221 * the domain of possible cases. \param dof The index of the degree of freedom 222 * to be retrieved from the structure of the modelled waveguide. \return This 223 * function returns the value of the requested degree of freedom. Should this 224 * dof not exist, 0 will be returnd. 225 */ 226 double get_dof(int dof) const; 227 228 /** 229 * This function sets the value of the dof provided to the given value. It is 230 * important to consider, that some dofs are non-writable (i.e. the values of 231 * the degrees of freedom on the boundary, like the radius of the 232 * input-connector cannot be changed). \param dof The index of the parameter 233 * to be changed. \param value The value, the dof should be set to. 234 */ 235 void set_dof(int dof, double value); 236 237 /** 238 * This is a getter for the values of degrees of freedom. A getter-setter 239 * interface was introduced since the values are estimated automatically 240 * during the optimization and non-physical systems should be excluded from 241 * the domain of possible cases. \param dof The index of the degree of freedom 242 * to be retrieved from the structure of the modelled waveguide. \return This 243 * function returns the value of the requested degree of freedom. Should this 244 * dof not exist, 0 will be returnd. 245 */ 246 double get_free_dof(int dof) const; 247 248 /** 249 * This function sets the value of the dof provided to the given value. It is 250 * important to consider, that some dofs are non-writable (i.e. the values of 251 * the degrees of freedom on the boundary, like the radius of the 252 * input-connector cannot be changed). \param dof The index of the parameter 253 * to be changed. \param value The value, the dof should be set to. 254 */ 255 void set_free_dof(int dof, double value); 256 257 /** 258 * Using this method unifies the usage of coordinates. This function takes a 259 * global \f$z\f$ coordinate (in the computational domain) and returns both a 260 * Sector-Index and an internal \f$z\f$ coordinate indicating which sector 261 * this coordinate belongs to and how far along in the sector it is located. 262 * \param double in_z global system \f$z\f$ coordinate for the transformation. 263 */ 264 std::pair<int, double> Z_to_Sector_and_local_z(double in_z) const; 265 266 /** 267 * Returns the complete length of the computational domain. 268 */ 269 double System_Length() const; 270 271 /** 272 * Returns the length of one sector 273 */ 274 double Sector_Length() const; 275 276 /** 277 * Returns the length of one layer 278 */ 279 double Layer_Length() const; 280 281 /** 282 * Returns the radius for a system-coordinate; 283 */ 284 double get_r(double in_z) const; 285 286 /** 287 * Returns the shift for a system-coordinate; 288 */ 289 double get_m(double in_z) const; 290 291 /** 292 * Returns the tilt for a system-coordinate; 293 */ 294 double get_v(double in_z) const; 295 296 int Z_to_Layer(double) const; 297 298 /** 299 * This vector of values saves the initial configuration 300 */ 301 Vector<double> InitialDofs; 302 303 /** 304 * Other objects can use this function to retrieve an array of the current 305 * values of the degrees of freedom of the functional we are optimizing. This 306 * also includes restrained degrees of freedom and other functions can be used 307 * to determine this property. This has to be done because in different cases 308 * the number of restrained degrees of freedom can vary and we want no logic 309 * about this in other functions. 310 */ 311 Vector<double> Dofs() const; 312 313 /** 314 * This function returns the number of unrestrained degrees of freedom of the 315 * current optimization run. 316 */ 317 unsigned int NFreeDofs() const; 318 319 /** 320 * This function returns the total number of DOFs including restrained ones. 321 * This is the lenght of the array returned by Dofs(). 322 */ 323 unsigned int NDofs() const; 324 325 /** 326 * Since Dofs() also returns restrained degrees of freedom, this function can 327 * be applied to determine if a degree of freedom is indeed free or 328 * restrained. "restrained" means that for example the DOF represents the 329 * radius at one of the connectors (input or output) and therefore we forbid 330 * the optimization scheme to vary this value. 331 */ 332 bool IsDofFree(int) const; 333 334 /** 335 * Console output of the current Waveguide Structure. 336 */ 337 void Print() const; 338 339 std::complex<double> evaluate_for_z(double z_in, Waveguide *); 340 341 std::complex<double> evaluate_for_z_with_sum(double, double, Waveguide *); 342 343 std::complex<double> gauss_product_2D_sphere(double z, int n, double R, 344 double Xc, double Yc, 345 Waveguide *in_w); 346 347 SpaceTransformation *st; 348 }; 349 350 #endif
